images.title: Philip Halling / Cross, Backwell churchyard
images.caption: Churchyard cross outside St Andrew's parish church, Backwell, North Somerset. The base is 15th-century. The shaft and head are replacements added in 1962.

images.title: FollowMeChaps / Crossroads in centre of Backwell
images.caption: Crossroads in centre of Backwell

images.title: Martin Bodman, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Backwell: Teagues Colliery. The waste tip of an early 19th century coal mine on Backwell Common, now covered in trees. James Teague (1750-1818), its developer, was an ironmaster and owner of coal pits in the Forest of Dean. For further information see Ralph Anstis, The Industrial Teagues and the Forest of Dean, Allan Sutton, 1990. Seen from one of the numerous public footpaths in the parish.

images.title: Brian Slater / Red deer stag
images.caption: Red deer stag In the fields of Manor Farm, Brockley, with Backwell outskirts on the hill behind.

description: This walk takes you around Backwell Lake in the North Somerset village of Backwell. There's a car park at the eastern side of the lake just north of the village, off Station Road. From here you can pick up a nice circular footpath heading around the lake for about half a mile. The site is also a nature reserve where you can look out for a variety of water loving birds on the water. Keep your eyes peeled for gadwall, shoveler, pochard, tufted duck, grey heron and mute swans as you make your way around the site. To extend the walk you can head north into neighbouring Nailsea where you could visit the splendid Ty Sculpture Trail . If you head south east of the village you could climb up to the Jubilee Stone where there are nice views over the area.
